definition: to accompany/to keep sb company/to assist/old variant of 賠|赔[pei2]

sentences.english: Hostesses are also writing best-selling books, be they on money management or the art of conversation.
sentences.chinese: 陪酒女們也寫出了暢銷書，講述如何理財和談話藝術。

sentences.english: Popular culture is also fueling hostessing’s popularity.
sentences.chinese: 通俗文化也使得陪酒職業更加普遍。

sentences.english: Her 17-year-old sister, who also wants to be a hostess, may succeed her.
sentences.chinese: 她17歲的妹妹也想成爲陪酒女，或許可能接替她。

sentences.english: Hostess wages are starting to fall to as little as $16 an hour.
sentences.chinese: 陪酒女的薪酬開始降到16美元一小時。

sentences.english: “Some people still say hostesses are wasting their life away, ” he said.
sentences.chinese: “還有些人仍然在說陪酒工作是浪費生命，”他說。

sentences.english: Her father was there to keep me company because I was a guest of honor and usually women did not eat with the guests.
sentences.chinese: 她父親把當作貴客要陪酒，而女人是不和客人同桌的。

sentences.english: I' ll be at the airport all morning with Mr. Sakai.
sentences.chinese: 我明天整個上午都在機場陪酒井先生。

definition: to work as a hostess in a bar or KTV
to work as a good-time girl/to prostitute oneself
to force sb to drink alcohol
karaoke hall/singing hall (venue for concerts of popular songs)
to trade sex for favorable treatment (career advancement, higher grades, rent-free accommodation etc)/to sleep in the same bed as one's child
